body.p: I am spending two or three weeks in Maysville, and have been requested to prepare an application for the pardon of Wm. Brookover, & send the same to you, which I have done.

I was one of the counsel employed to aid in the prosecution of Brookover. We prosecuted him about 3 years -- had 2, 3 or 4 hung Juries before we were able to convict him. After he was convicted he carried the case to the court of Appeals, and there being no error in the record the judgement was affirmed.

Mr. Brookover then broke jail and hid in different parts of the United States from 1856 to 1860 or 1861, where, it appears that he entered the Federal Army, and has fought the rebels well for
three long years. He is sick, and now in the Federal Hospital in Arkansas, at Pine Bluff. His friends fear that he will die in the Hospital. His wife obtained a divorce on account of his conviction, and is now lying on her death bed near Maysville. His only little son, about 13, is with her.
I prosecuted him with all the vigor I could command, believeing that he was guilty; but surely this is a clear case for pardon.

Please direct your pardon to me at Maysville, if it is your pleasure to grant him a pardon. The friends desire your early action on the application, in view of the danger to the life of the applicant by lying longer in the Hospital.

Very Respectfully,
Your friend,
John L. Scott.
